moves.2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nb5: That move looks to complete white's development.
moves.16... Nd3: 16 ... Nd3 Dubbed Octopus Knight by Raymond Keene.
moves.22... Qxd6: And looks like black's development completes here.
moves.23. g3 Nd7 24. Bg2 Qf6 25. a3 a5 26. axb: Ironically, two moves from now she has to move back to d2.
moves.30. f3 Qxd6: 30 ... Qxd6 31 fxg4 Pawn exchange that opens up the f file.
moves.31. fxg4 Qd4+ 32. Kh1 Nf6 33. Rf4: Threatens to capture the queen, but she needs to stay on the a7-h1 diagonal, where a7 is the only safe square for her.
moves.33... Ne4: ...Or black can interposition with the knight. 33 ... Ne4 is stronger than 33 ... Qa7.
moves.34. Qxd3: This is why Ne4 is stronger. 34 ... Nf2+ forks the king and queen, except for that f4 rook...
moves.34... Nf2+ 35. Rxf2: But it gives black a free queen for his LSB.
moves.35... Bxd3 36. Rfd2: White played this instead of 36 Rxd3 to put pressure on black's queen.
moves.36... Qe3: ...But then now e3 is a safe square for the queen while staying on the a7-h1 diagonal.
moves.37. Rd2xd3: Capturing the bishop while threatening the queen.
moves.37... Rc1: Black would want to exchange now.
moves.38. Nb2: White decides not to go for the exchange yet.
moves.38... Qf2: But now she's safe on f2.
moves.39. Nd2: 39 Nd2? Allows black to mate in 3. Nc3 would also allow mate. Perhaps Rxc1?
moves.39... Rxd1+: White has no choice but to recapture now.
